item.title: The Top 5 Linux Distros for Gaming: A Newbie’s Fast-Track
item.description:
The Truth About Distros

Let’s get one thing straight: Linux is Linux. Whether you use Arch, Debian, or Fedora, the underlying technology that runs your games—the Kernel, Mesa drivers, and Proton—is largely the same. Once you understand how to use a package manager and distinguish between a “stable” and “rolling” release, the brand name on the boot screen becomes secondary.

However, for someone jumping over from Windows today, you don’t want to spend four hours configuring a window manager just to launch Cyberpunk 2077. You want a system that is ready for war out of the box. These 5 distributions respect your time by providing the best pre-configured gaming environments for newcomers.

item.title: The Ultimate Guide to Gaming on Arch Linux
item.description:
Introduction

If you’ve spent years on Windows, you’ve been taught that “gaming on Linux” is either a myth or a headache. But for those of us who grew up tinkering from our young days to the depths of the Arch Wiki, we know the truth. On Arch, you don’t just “run” games… You optimize the entire environment for them.

With an AMD CPU/GPU combo and the right configuration, your Linux machine isn’t just a daily driver, it’s a high-performance monster machine that you actually own.
